adminNotes.content: Consistently high ratings and professionalism. Verified all credentials successfully.

suspensionHistory.reason: Multiple cancellations within policy violation threshold
suspensionHistory.notes: Final warning issued. Insurance verification expired and not renewed.

adminNotes.content: Multiple last-minute cancellations reported. Monitor closely after suspension.
One dispute resolved in company's favor. Payment processed promptly.

suspensionHistory.reason: Multiple payment disputes and late payments to technicians
suspensionHistory.notes: Must resolve outstanding payment issues before reactivation. 3 disputes currently unresolved.

adminNotes.content: Pattern of late payments identified. Multiple technicians complained about delayed compensation.
Under investigation for potential policy violations. Monitoring all future bookings.

sampleDisputes.description: Technician claims company added 3 hours of overtime work that was not included in the final payment. Company disputes the overtime hours were pre-approved.

evidence.description: Text message conversation about extending the event

messages.content: The event ran 3 hours over the agreed time. I stayed for the full duration and handled breakdown. The text messages show the production manager asking me to stay.
While the event did run longer, overtime was not pre-approved as per our booking terms. The technician should have confirmed overtime rates before agreeing to stay.

I've reviewed the evidence. The text messages show a clear request from the production manager to extend work. While pre-approval is ideal, the company representative did request the additional work. I'm ruling in favor of the technician for 3 hours overtime at 1.5x rate.

resolution.reasoning: Text messages confirm company representative requested additional hours. Technician completed the work in good faith. Company must pay 3 hours overtime at 1.5x rate ($75 x 1.5 x 3 = $337.50).

sampleDisputes.description: Company claims technician was a no-show for a corporate event. Technician claims she arrived on time but venue information was incorrect.

evidence.description: Original booking with venue address: 1234 Market St, Suite 500
Screenshot of technician at 1234 Market St at event time
Text messages between technician and venue security

messages.content: Our technician never showed up for the event. We had to scramble to find a replacement. The event was at Suite 800, not Suite 500.

I arrived at the address in the booking details (Suite 500) 15 minutes early. Building security couldn't find the event. I tried calling the contact number but no answer. The booking clearly said Suite 500.

The booking details confirm Suite 500 was listed. The company updated the venue to Suite 800 internally but never updated the booking. This is a company error. No fault to technician. Full cancellation fee waived for both parties.

resolution.reasoning: Incorrect venue information in booking. Company's internal miscommunication. Technician made good faith effort to fulfill booking. No penalties applied to either party.

sampleDisputes.description: Company claims technician's audio mix was substandard, causing feedback issues during live performance. Seeking full refund of $5,200. Technician claims venue equipment was faulty and was not disclosed in booking.

evidence.description: Original booking agreement and equipment rider
Photo of faulty mixing console with visible damage
Email thread between technician and venue technical director

messages.content: The audio quality was unacceptable. Multiple feedback incidents disrupted the performance. We hired an experienced A1 and this should not have happened. We're requesting a full refund.

The venue's console had malfunctioning preamps on channels 8-12, which was not disclosed. I did the best I could with faulty equipment. I documented the issues and informed the technical director during setup. The equipment rider specified a working DiGiCo SD10, but what was provided was not functioning properly.

This is a high-value dispute that requires careful review. I'm requesting additional documentation from both parties. Company: please provide any pre-event equipment checks. Technician: please provide detailed notes from sound check and any communication with venue staff.
Internal note: This may require third-party equipment inspection. Technician has strong documentation. Need to verify if equipment issues were disclosed pre-event.

sampleDisputes.description: Company claims technician damaged a wireless microphone receiver ($850 value). Technician claims damage existed before the event.

evidence.description: Pre-event equipment checklist signed by both parties

messages.content: The wireless receiver was damaged during the event. It was working fine before. We need $850 for replacement.
I noted the cracked display on the pre-event checklist. The company representative signed acknowledging existing damage. I have a copy of the signed form.
The pre-event checklist clearly shows the damage was noted and acknowledged before the event. Dispute resolved in technician's favor. No liability.

resolution.reasoning: Pre-event documentation confirms damage existed before the event and was acknowledged by company representative. No fault to technician.

sampleDisputes.description: Company cancelled booking 36 hours before event (within 48-hour cancellation policy). Technician requesting 50% cancellation fee. Company claims cancellation was due to venue closure (force majeure).

evidence.description: Official venue closure notice due to water main break

messages.content: I declined other opportunities for this date. The cancellation was within 48 hours, so I'm requesting the 50% cancellation fee as per platform policy.

The venue had a water main break and was forced to close. This is a force majeure situation beyond our control. We're willing to rebook for a future date but shouldn't be penalized for circumstances outside our control.
Company, can you provide documentation that you attempted to secure an alternate venue? And timeline of when you were notified by the venue? This will help determine if force majeure applies.

flaggedContent.content: Worst technician ever. Complete waste of money. Don't hire this person unless you want your event ruined.
flaggedContent.additionalDetails: This review is from a booking that was cancelled by the company 2 hours before the event. I never actually worked this event. This appears to be retaliation.
flaggedContent.actionNotes: Review removed. Verified that booking was cancelled by company before event occurred. Technician never provided services. Warning issued to company for false review.

flaggedContent.content: This company is a bunch of [offensive language]. They don't pay on time and treat people like [offensive language].
flaggedContent.additionalDetails: Automatically flagged for profanity and offensive language

flaggedContent.content: Professional audio engineer with 15+ years experience. Worked with Beyonc√©, Taylor Swift, and Coldplay world tours.
flaggedContent.additionalDetails: We know the touring crews for these artists. This person has never worked with them. False advertising.
flaggedContent.actionNotes: Contacted user to verify claims. Unable to provide evidence. Bio edited to remove false claims. User warned about accuracy in profile.

flaggedContent.content: Profile photo appears to be inappropriate/not professional
flaggedContent.additionalDetails: Photo appears to show the user at a party, not professional attire or setting.
flaggedContent.actionNotes: Photo reviewed. While casual, it does not violate community guidelines. Photo shows user at a legitimate industry event. Not inappropriate.

flaggedContent.content: Hey, let's take this conversation off the platform. Here's my personal cell: [phone number]. We can work out a better rate if we skip the platform fees.
